attributes.title: Do people choose distinct labels for minimal groups in order to increase group distinctiveness?
attributes.description: This study investigates people’s perceptions of arbitrary symbols that novel social groups are identified with. Specifically, we are asking whether people would predict that two minimal social groups (e.g. Group X and Group Y) would try to choose distinct group markers instead of similar ones (i.e. choosing different sounding names as group labels instead of similar sounding ones) to increase the distinctiveness of their group.

q2.value: The number of participants who will predict that the second group chose the label which is similar to the first group's label will be smaller than the number of people who will predict that the second group chose the label which sounds different than the first group's label.

q3.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: Personnel who interact directly with the study subjects (either human or non-human subjects) will not be aware of the assigned treatments. (Commonly known as “double blind”)
For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value: The experiment will have a 2 between subjects conditions. Label set is the between subjects variable, and it refers to the group label options participants will be shown in the experiment: Half of the participants will be told that the first group chose the name "Aalborg" and will be asked which one of these names the second group chose: "Alaborg" (similar label option) or "Skalunda" (different label option). The other half of the participants will be told that the first group chose the name "Thurso" and will be asked whether the group chose the name "Truso" (similar label option) or "Wolin" (different label option).

q7.value: Each participant will be assigned to one of the between subjects conditions according to Qualtrics' automatic randomization criteria with the only consideration being allocating an equal number of sample size to each cell.

q8.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: Participants on Mturk Prime US database will be invited to participate in the study in exchange of one US Dollar for their participation.

q11.value: Our target sample size is 100 participants.

question.value:
The main DV is participants’ choice of label: First, participants will be introduced with two minimal groups and told that the members of each group will pick a name for their group. Then they will be told that members of one of the groups picked their name, “Aalborg(/Thurso)”, and then they will be asked which name, they think, did this second group choose.
One of the options will be similar to the other group’s name (“Alaborg” [/Truso]) and the second option will sound more different (“Skalunda”[/Wolin]).

First, the effect of the label set will be tested using a chi-square test. If these is no difference between the two groups in terms of the number of participants who chose the different option over the similar option, data will be collapsed across of these two groups. Then the number of participants who chose the similar option versus the different option will be compared using a binomial test.

q22.value:
In order to test whether participant’s perception of these two groups’ characteristics will be shaped by their choice of label, we will collect data on these two variables:

Secondary DV1 aims to measure people’s perception on the distinctiveness between these two groups. It will be calculated as the difference score between these two questions:
“How similar is a Group X member to a typical Group X member?” (on a scale of 1-7, 1 being “very different”, 7 being “very similar”)
and 
“How similar is a Group X member to a typical Group Y member?” (on a scale of 1-7, 1 being “very different”, 7 being “very similar”)

Secondary DV2: The difference score between the amount of money allocated to Group 
    X vs Group Y by a member of one of these groups, measured by this 
    question:

“Think about a member of the Group X. This person is responsible for preparing two dinner parties; one for the Group X and one for the Group Y. This person has a 300$ budget in total for both dinners. How much money, do you think, this person would allocate for the dinner of each group?”

We expect that compared to the participants who picked the different sounding label for the second group, participants who picked the more similar sounding label would think these groups are more similar to each other, and they would expect the difference in allocated resources to the ingroup versus to the outgroup to be smaller. 
For this analysis we will first group participants who chose the similar sounding label vs. the different sounding label. The effects of the label choice (different sounding label vs. similar sounding label) will be tested using a one way between-subjects ANOVA for each dependent variable.

We also expect certain demographic traits and political affiliation of participants may be related to the way that participants attend to the group identification cues. Therefore, we will look for possible relationships between demographic variables (age and gender) and political affiliation and the dependent variables.

In addition, participants will also be asked about why they chose one label option over the other in order to investigate whether they make consistent use of certain arguments for their choice of the similar or the different group label.

Since the groups will be named after Scandinavian cities, these names might be familiar to some participants, and this familiarity might affect their perception of the groups. Hence, we will ask participants whether they have heard of these names before. Data will be tested with and without the participants who are familiar with these names.

registration_responses.q2: The number of participants who will predict that the second group chose the label which is similar to the first group's label will be smaller than the number of people who will predict that the second group chose the label which sounds different than the first group's label.

For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

attributes.title: EVIDENCE-BASED CLASSIFICATION IN WHEELCHAIR SPORTS: A SYSTEMATIC REVIEW
attributes.description: A systematic Review of evidence-based classification en wheelchair sports

summary.value: Objective: Conduct a systematic review of tests, instruments and sensors that were used to make the classification of wheelchair sports more objective. Design: Systematic Review of literature. Data Sources: PubMed and ScienceDirect. Eligibility Criteria: Studies were eligible for inclusion according to the following criteria: (I) involving wheelchair sports, (II) only papers written in English, (III) presents quantitative data of evidence-based classification, (IV) only research studies were selected. Results: Wheelchair rugby is the sport that has more research on the functional classification based on evidence, the main parameter for assessing the strength of upper limbs and muscles the trunk. To assess these aspects, the main test applied was that of isometric strength using equipment that evaluates strength as load cells and dynamometers.  Summary: Through this work, it was observed that the field of technology can be a great ally in the process for classification based on evidence. Through equipment and sensors that provide objective measurements of parameters that are evaluated in the classification process, it is possible to validate simple tests that can be applied in the field and thus obtain reliable values.

registration_responses.summary: Objective: Conduct a systematic review of tests, instruments and sensors that were used to make the classification of wheelchair sports more objective. Design: Systematic Review of literature. Data Sources: PubMed and ScienceDirect. Eligibility Criteria: Studies were eligible for inclusion according to the following criteria: (I) involving wheelchair sports, (II) only papers written in English, (III) presents quantitative data of evidence-based classification, (IV) only research studies were selected. Results: Wheelchair rugby is the sport that has more research on the functional classification based on evidence, the main parameter for assessing the strength of upper limbs and muscles the trunk. To assess these aspects, the main test applied was that of isometric strength using equipment that evaluates strength as load cells and dynamometers.  Summary: Through this work, it was observed that the field of technology can be a great ally in the process for classification based on evidence. Through equipment and sensors that provide objective measurements of parameters that are evaluated in the classification process, it is possible to validate simple tests that can be applied in the field and thus obtain reliable values.

attributes.title: The Effect of Mechanical Stimulation, i.e. Exercise on Bone Health in Patients and Survivors of Hematological Malignancies:
attributes.description:
Due to the disease, pharmacological treatments and modified lifestyle, the musculoskeletal system of patients and survivors of bone marrow-related hematological malignancies can be severely impaired, even years after complete remission. These adverse effects range from low bone mineral density (BMD), diminished bone microstructure and/or muscle weakness to, more severely, clinical osteoporosis with vertebral compaction or even osteonecrosis. 
Physical or mechanical stimulation, for example in the form of exercise has been shown to beneficially impact  bone health in osteoporotic as well as in healthy individuals, which leads to the following question: “Do mechanical stimulation interventions benefit bone health and quality(BMD) in bone marrow-related hematological malignancies?" We aim to perform a systematic review of the available literature and possibly a meta-analysis to assess the effect size. We hypothesize that a positive effect on bone quality will be observed in favor of intervention groups.

datacompletion.value: No, data collection has not begun

registration_responses.datacompletion: No, data collection has not begun

attributes.title: Investigating affective cognitive control and its effect on mental health and well-being in care-experienced young people compared to their peers
attributes.description: There is extensive evidence that care-experienced young people have poorer mental health than their peers, attributed at least partly to early, often prolonged, exposure to maltreatment. However, there has been little exploration of the mechanisms that may link these experiences to their mental health outcomes, limiting knowledge of potential intervention targets. In this study we focus on the potential role of affective control, a core cognitive building block associated with emotion regulation and mental health outcomes. We will explore three key questions: (i) whether care-experienced young people have poorer affective control than sex and age-matched peers; (ii) whether the affective control of care-experienced young people is associated with broad internalising and externalising problems, post-traumatic stress symptoms, and school well-being; (iii) whether associations between affective control and these emotional and school well-being outcomes are partially explained by emotion regulation capacity. We aim to recruit 71 care-experienced young people aged 11-18, which will be compared to data already collected from young people at secondary school. Participants will complete a battery of computer-based tasks and questionnaires. This is comprised of three experimental tasks measuring affective control ability, a brief standardised IQ test and validated questionnaires measuring internalising and externalising problems, post-traumatic stress symptoms, school well-being and emotion regulation.

summary.value:
In this study, we will investigate the affective control ability of care-experienced young people. We will explore whether these young people have poorer affective control than their peers, whether affective control is associated with their mental health outcomes and whether emotion regulation can partially explain this association. This study is unique, as there is currently minimal research investigating the core psychological or cognitive processes that may influence the development or maintenance of mental health difficulties in young people in care, or how these processes may affect their broader well-being. By exploring affective control as a potential transdiagnostic mechanism, this work aims to identify whether this may be a useful intervention or prevention target, while also improving our understanding of the mental health related needs of care-experienced young people.

A protocol for this registration is attached in a PDF document. This document contains the study’s aims and hypotheses, ethical considerations and a detailed outline of the method and design.

registration_responses.summary:

This study is unique, as there is currently minimal research investigating the core psychological or cognitive processes that may influence the development or maintenance of mental health difficulties in young people in care, or how these processes may affect their broader well-being. By exploring affective control as a potential transdiagnostic mechanism, this work aims to identify whether this may be a useful intervention or prevention target, while also improving our understanding of the mental health related needs of care-experienced young people.

attributes.title: Ideology, Prejudice, and Compliance with Public Health Recomendations
attributes.description: Broadly speaking, those who align themselves with a more conservative political viewpoint can be seen as possessing a more authoritarian stance and belief in social dominance (Duckitt & Sibley, 2010). As such, these individuals are likely to interact differently with the guidance given by figures of authority around the current COVID-19 pandemic, whilst there is little research concerning those who score low on the above traits, it is likely that they too will interact differently with these recommendations.  It is likely that an increased state of anxiety increases this (Van ‘t Veer & Sleegers, 2019).

q1.value: Ryan Statton, Jaysan Charlesford, Anna Kharko, Joshua Ainslie, Imogen Payne

q2.value:
Political Ideology will be predictive of Compliance with Public Health Recommendations.
Political Ideology will be predictive of current anxiety.
Anxiety will be predictive of Compliance with Public Health Recommendations.
Anxiety will partially moderate the relationship between Political Ideology and Compliance with Public Health Recommendations.

q3.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: Repeated measures survey design, participants will respond to all items.

q7.value: Four blocks will be presented in a fixed order, the order of presentation of scales within these blocks will be randomised.

q8.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
Participants will be recruited via four methods: 1) School of Psychology ‘participation points’ scheme; 2) volunteers recruited through social media (i.e., Facebook, Twitter); 3) volunteers recruited through websites where individuals choose to take part in psychological research for recreational and educational purposes (e.g., Social Psychology on the Net; Reddit, r/samplesize); 4) referral from the completion of the opposite survey stream. 

Participants in the latter three recruitment streams will self-select by clicking a link posted by the research team. From this point on, all participants will have an identical experience of the procedure. Participants must be at least 18 years old. Participants will be entered into a prize draw to win either a £100, £50, £25, or £25 Amazon Voucher.

q12.value: This is in line with Westland’s (2010) Lower Bounds method for calculating sample size (calculated using Soper’s SEM sample calculator (Soper, 2020)). These are calculated at .8 power, and using a medium effect size of .3 (Cohen, 1988).

q13.value: Data collection will stop when the target sample is reached or two weeks have elapsed from the launch of the survey.

question.value: Participants will then respond to the Social Dominance Orientation (SDO) Scale and the Right-Wing Authoritarianism (RWA) Scale in a counterbalanced order. Next, both streams will collect anxiety information, asking participants to respond to the State-Trait Anxiety Inventory (STAI), the Padua Inventory, the Mini International Neuropsychiatric Interview (MINI), and the Social Phobia Scale. Participants will also see a series of 25 questions around compliance with current Public Health recommendations in relation to COVID-19.
SEM (see diagram attached).

attributes.title: Ideology, Prejudice, and Compliance with Public Health Recomendations
attributes.description: Broadly speaking, those who align themselves with a more conservative political view point can be seen as possessing a more authoritarian stance and belief in social dominance (Duckitt & Sibley, 2010). As such, these individuals are likely to interact differently with guidance given by figures of authority around the current COVID-19 pandemic, whilst there is little research concerning those who score low on the above traits, it is likely that they too will interact different with these recommendations. A final, unknown factor is the relationship that the current increase in pathogenic anxiety and disgust will interact with these dimensions and compliance to recommendations.  Inbar et al. (2012) found that those more likely to vote to the political right also demonstrate higher disgust sensitivity, as such are more aware of potential microbial infection, coupled with Faulkner at al.’s (2004) link between disease avoidance and contemporary xenophobia, it would seem that this population is more likely that others to be avoidant of potential sources of infection, thus more likely to comply with public health recommendations. I tis likely that an increased state of anxiety on increases this (Van ‘t Veer & Sleegers, 2019).

q1.value: Ryan Statton, Jaysan Charlesford, Anna Kharko, Joshua Ainslie, Imogen Payne

q2.value:
Political Ideology is predictive of Disgust Sensitivity. 
Political Ideology is predictive of COVID-19 Prejudice. 
Political Ideology is partially predictive of Anxiety.
Anxiety is partially predictive of Disgust Sensitivity.
Anxiety is partially predictive of COVID-19 Prejudice. 
Disgust Sensitivity is predictive of COVID-19 Prejudice.
The relationship between Political Ideology and Disgust Sensitivity is partially mediated by Anxiety. 
The relationship between Political Ideology and COVID-19 Prejudice is partially mediated by Anxiety and Disgust Sensitivity.

attributes.title: The effects of a temporal framing manipulation on environmentalism: A replication and extension
attributes.description:
Baldwin and Lammers (2016) recently published a program of research demonstrating that conservatives are more susceptible to pro-environmental messages that are past-focused compared to the same messages when framed as future-focused. In their third study, they showed participants a series of images comparing pristine and degraded environments to induce past and future temporal focus in the participants. These were labelled to depict changes from the current state of the environment to how it used to be (demonstrating pristine environments of the past, i.e., past-focused manipulation), or how it will be in the future (demonstrating degraded natural environments of the future, i.e., future-focused manipulation). Their research showed that past-focused comparisons attenuated the negative effect of political conservatism (measured with a single item liberal to conservative scale) on environmental attitudes (measured with the New Ecological Paradigm). That is, political conservatism was a weaker predictor of environmental attitudes among those who first viewed past-focused comparisons. 

In an effort to replicate and extend on their research, we conducted a study in 2019 among participants based in the United States recruited via crowdsourcing site Prolific. We presented participants with the same image-pairs as seen in Study 3 of Baldwin and Lammers (2016). However, we aimed to extend their work to test whether the temporal framing effect extended to increases in other forms of environmentalism, such as increased willingness to engage in pro-environmental action (measured using Liu and Sibley’s (2012) willingness to sacrifice scale), support for climate change policy (measured using Bateman & O’Connor’s (2016) policy support scale), and/or belief in climate change. We also employed a multidimensional measure of political ideology, measuring this construct with social dominance orientation (using Ho et al.’s (2015) SDO7 scale), and testing the utility of the two dimensions of SDO (Dominance and Anti-egalitarianism) in place of the single item political orientation measure. 

Our preliminary analyses found differences in responses by condition across the political spectrum only for perceived certainty that climate change is happening. Specifically, while those with a more liberal political orientation were equally certain that climate change is happening, regardless of framing condition, those who were more conservative reported greater certainty after viewing the past comparisons. However, this interaction did not replicate for the other three environmental-outcome measures we included, despite more than doubling Baldwin and Lammers’ (2016) sample size (from 200 participants to just over 500 participants). We had planned to test several potential explanations for the temporal framing effect, such as differences in perceived certainty that the environmental changes have or will occur. However, in the absence of a significant interaction between political orientation and framing condition, comprehensive tests of these explanations were not possible. As an initial exploratory test of these explanations, we regressed political orientation, framing condition, and the interaction term on two explanatory variables (certainty ratings and temporal distance). We found that political orientation and temporal framing condition interacted only to predict certainty ratings, with individuals identifying as moderately to very conservative significantly more certain that the environmental changes depicted have occurred (i.e., if they were in the past-focused condition), than they will occur (future-focused condition).

This study will follow up on possible reasons for the failure to replicate Baldwin and Lammers (2016) finding of a temporal framing interaction with political orientation. From our exploratory analyses, we propose that there may be four potential reasons as to why the effect did not replicate in our study, which we outline below: 

1.	In our first study, we asked participants to rate the likely causes of environmental changes in the photo pairs, while Baldwin and Lammers asked the extent that each image demonstrated the effects of climate change. Using a similar temporal framing approach, Lammers and Baldwin (2018) eliminated the temporal framing effect when asking people to carefully evaluate their framed message, suggesting that this engages a different kind of processing style (central, rather than peripheral) that inoculates participants from the effects of the frame. It is possible that asking participants to rate causes engages a similar level of scepticism and/or inoculation, hence erasing the effect. To test this possible explanation, in addition to the temporal focus manipulation (past- versus future-comparisons), this study will also include a cover story manipulation, where participants are randomly assigned to either rate the causes of the depicted environmental changes (as in our study) or the extent they depict the effects of climate change (as in Baldwin & Lammers). 

2.	Another explanation for our non-replication is that we employed different outcome measures. Baldwin and Lammers (2016) used the new environmental paradigm scale, which is the most widely used measure of pro-environmentalism. Based on criticisms of the scale (e.g. whether it measures attitudes, beliefs, values, or a worldview), our first study instead included a host of different environmental variables that were specifically related to climate change. We note that some framing effects do not extend to other forms of environmentalism (e.g. Levine & Kline, 2017), and therefore we include the same new environmental paradigm scale from Baldwin and Lammers in this study to test whether the effect replicates on the same outcome measure. This is in addition to the other outcome variables included in our first study (climate change belief, certainty that climate change is happening, willingness to make sacrifices for the environment, climate change policy support, and agreement to sign a petition). To control for possible order effects, we will randomise the presentation of these outcome variables. 

3.	Another aim of our first study was to replicate the temporal framing effect with a multidimensional measure of political ideology. Specifically, some work suggests that the anti-egalitarian dimension/factor of social dominance orientation (SDO-E) is particularly relevant in predicting environment-relevant attitudes (Stanley et al., 2017) when compared to the dominance dimension/factor (SDO-D). In our exploratory analyses, we put SDO-E in place of political orientation, and when doing so we did replicate the interaction with condition on both climate change certainty and policy support. In this study, we expand the focus on the influence of more foundational attitudes towards how the world ought to be structured (SDO) and controlled (right-wing authoritarianism; RWA). To build on the exploratory findings that replicated the effect across SDO-E, this study will include a measure of right-wing authoritarianism, which is another ideological component underlying both political attitudes and predicting lower levels of pro-environmental attitudes and climate change belief (e.g. Häkkinen & Akrami, 2014; Schultz & Stone, 1994).

4.	Finally, although we took care to sample from the same target population as Baldwin and Lammers (i.e., those based in the United States), the political context has changed since the original study was conducted. When Baldwin and Lammers asked participants to think to the past, they did so at a time when the Democratic Party was in charge. Our data were collected under the Trump administration, who campaigned on a return to the past (e.g. “Make America Great Again”), and so it is possible that past comparisons are no longer effective for conservatives under this context as they have already returned to their ‘desired’ past. Given this, the study proposed below will recruit participants from the United Kingdom.

q1.value: Samantha Stanley, Edward John Roy Clarke, Anna Klas, Iain Walker

q2.value:
H1: Regardless of temporal framing or rating condition, there will be a main effect of political orientation such that political conservatism will predict lower environmentalism (across all outcome variables).

H2: Where there is a significant interaction effect of temporal framing by political orientation, it is expected that the past focused environmental images will attenuate the negative effect of political orientation on environmentalism compared to future focused images. 

Two of the potential explanations (Points 1 and 2) for our failure to replicate the temporal framing by political orientation interaction found by Baldwin and Lammers (2016) are testable in this second study we are running. Predictions are as follows:

H3: If asking participants to rate the likely causes of environmental changes inoculated them against the temporal framing interaction, then we expect to replicate Baldwin and Lammer’s (2016) temporal framing by political orientation interaction among those participants who rated the extent the image pairs depicted climate change, and not among those rating the likely causes of the environmental changes depicted. 

H4: If the temporal frame only moderates the effect of political orientation on pro-environmental attitudes, we expect to replicate Baldwin and Lammer’s (2016) temporal framing by political orientation interaction only when scores on the new environmental paradigm are included as the dependent variable, and not for any other outcome variables (climate change belief, policy support, etc.) 

The main purpose of our replication study was initially to test different explanations for the temporal framing effect interaction. If the interaction is replicated, then we aim to test the extent to which the effect is explained/mediated by perceived certainty of environmental changes, nostalgia, past positive time perspective, and temporal distance, in a series of exploratory analyses. Of these, we only have a prediction for the certainty explanation as based on prior literature:

H5: The interaction between temporal framing condition and political orientation will be explained/mediated by participant’s ratings of how certain they are that the changes had happened (past-focused condition) or will (future-focused condition) happen. Participants who are more politically conservative will report increased environmentalism after viewing the past comparisons (versus future comparisons), and this effect will be explained by greater ratings of certainty.

q3.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: Personnel who interact directly with the study subjects (either human or non-human subjects) will not be aware of the assigned treatments. (Commonly known as “double blind”)

q5.value: Double blind, with Qualtrics randomly assigning participants to one of the four possible conditions.

question.value: Between subjects design with two experimental manipulations (2x2 design): temporal focus (past vs. future) and picture rating manipulation (rate causes vs. rate effects), and a continuous independent variable (political orientation).

q7.value: The study will be conducted online in Qualtrics, and therefore participants will be randomly assigned to a temporal focus condition (past vs future) and picture rating (rate causes vs rate effects) condition. Participants will be randomly allocated to one of these four possible conditions using the block randomization feature of Qualtrics.

q8.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
We will recruit participants via the online recruiting platform Prolific. We will restrict participation to only those living in the United Kingdom. Participants will be paid 1.83USD upon completion for the 10-15 minute experiment. 

To recruit participants across the political spectrum from this platform, we will initially open the study for the collection of 200 participants. We will then check for political bias, especially if there are a high percentage of participants from one side of the political spectrum. If this is present (e.g. left-wing voters overrepresented) then we will post another set restricted to those participants who indicated a right-wing political orientation on their Prolific profile. We will continue to post the study in alternating sets recruiting openly and restricting to right-wing participants to achieve an even distribution of left- and right-wing participants. Participants will be prohibited from signing up to both assignments to ensure that any individual can only participate in this research once.

q11.value: We aim to recruit a total of 1000 participants.

q12.value: Baldwin and Lammers (2016) detected the temporal framing effect with a total sample of 200 participants. We aim to replicate their study with the addition of a second independent variable (with 2 levels), and test both moderated moderation and mediated moderation models. Although there is no consensus in the literature on how to conduct a power analysis for Johnson-Neyman analyses or the models we aim to test, our target sample size is 1000 participants to ensure we have around 250 participants per condition to increase the likelihood that we have adequately powered the study.

q13.value: To account for possible incomplete responses, we will stop posting new sign ups when 1100 participants have completed our study.

question.value:
Each participant will be randomly assigned to view past- or future-focused images, which were originally used in Baldwin and Lammers (2016). There are fourteen image-pairs, with a pristine environment on the left and degraded environment on the right. In the past-focused condition, these images are labeled ‘Past’ and ‘Present’, while in the future-focused condition, they are labeled ‘Present’ and ‘Future’. 

Instructions to participants: 

Past condition: On the next few screens you will be asked to rate some images demonstrating the effects of climate change. These are actual images showing how the present has changed from the past. 

Future condition: On the next few screens you will be asked to rate some images demonstrating the effects of climate change. These images are artists' renditions, or  images, showing how the present is likely to change in the future given our scientific understanding of climate change.

Images will be shown one at a time, and after each image participants will also be randomly assigned to rate either the causes or effects:

Causes condition: What do you think might be the main cause of this change to the environment? (sliding scale from entirely natural (0) to entirely human caused (100)

Effects condition: How much does this image demonstrate the effects of climate change? (sliding scale from not at all (0) to completely (100)

Predictor variables: 

Political ideology will be measured with the single item “Where would you place yourself on a scale from 0 to 10, where 0 means the left and 10 means the right?”, with responses from 0 (left-wing) to 10 (right-wing). 

Social dominance orientation will be measured with Ho et al.’s (2015) shortened SDO7 scale, with four items measuring SDO-E and four measuring SDO-D on a 7-point Likert scale from 1 (strongly disagree) to 7 (strongly agree). 

Right-wing authoritarianism will be measured with Duckitt et al.’s (2010) Authoritarianism-Conservatism-Traditionalism scale, with six items to measure each of the three components of RWA on a 7-point Likert scale from 1 (strongly disagree) to 7 (strongly agree). 

Potential mediating variables: 

State nostalgia will be measured with the three items taken from Baldwin, White and Sullivan (2017). Participants rate the extent they feel nostalgic, sentimental, and longing from 1 (not at all) to 5 (a great deal). Three future-focused emotions developed for this study were also included (excited for the future, looking forward to what comes next in life, eagerly anticipating the future), which are rated on the same scale. 

Past-positive time perspective will be measured with three items from Zhang et al.’s shortened scale. Participants are asked how characteristic of them three statements are, which they respond to from 1 (very untrue of me) to 5 (very true of me). 

Temporal distance of climate change is measured with Loy and Spence’s (2020) three item scale (e.g. “Climate change effects will mostly occur in the future”), with responses from 1 (strongly disagree) to 7 (strongly agree).  

At the end of the survey, participants will be asked to reflect on how certain they are that the images depicted in the photographs have happened (past-focused condition) or will happen (future-focused condition). Responses are recorded on a sliding scale from 0 (not at all certain) to 100 (completely certain). 

Outcome variables: 

Climate change beliefs are measured with two related items (‘Climate change is real’, and ‘Climate change is caused by humans’) on a 7-point scale from 1 (strongly disagree) to 7 (strongly agree). 

We also measure certainty that climate change is happening with the item ‘How certain are you that climate change is happening’ from 0 (not at all certain) to 100 (completely certain). Any participant that responds with 1 or above is presented with a second question, ‘What do you think is the cause of these changes in climate?’ on a sliding scale from caused entirely by humans to caused entirely by natural variation.  

Dunlap et al.’s (2000) 15-item new environmental paradigm scale will be included, with eight pro-trait items and seven con-trait items. Responses are from 1 (strongly disagree) to 5 (strongly agree). 

We include Liu and Sibley’s (2012) two items measuring the extent to which individuals are willing to make sacrifices to their standard of living and daily routine, from 1 (definitely no) to 7 (definitely yes). 

Bateman and O’Connor’s (2016) policy support scale is also included to gauge support for mitigation strategies (6 items) and adaptation strategies (5 items) from 1 (strongly disagree) to 7 (strongly agree). 

We also include a proxy behavioural measure, where participants are presented with two screenshots of climate change petitions, one labelled ‘Stop Gov’t HOAX Of Climate Change’, and the other ‘Acknowledge the Reality of Climate Change’, and record which, if any, participants indicate they will sign.

We will calculate mean scores for multi-item measures. For those measures with several dimensions (e.g. SDO, RWA, policy support), mean scores will be computed separately for each component of the scale (For SDO: SDO-E, SDO-D; RWA: Authoritarianism, Conventionalism, Traditionalism; Policy support: Mitigation strategies, Adaptation strategies). 

This also applies to the measure of pro-environmental attitudes, we will create a mean score of the pro-trait items (new environmental paradigm), to be consistent with the 8 item mean score used in Baldwin and Lammers (2016). We will also average responses to the con-trait (dominant social paradigm) items to be used separately.

We will use the same data analytic strategy as used in Baldwin and Lammers (2016) to regress each environmental outcome variable separately onto condition (past, future), political orientation, and the interaction term (condition X political orientation). This tests H1 (main effect of political orientation on environmentalism), and H2 (condition X political orientation interaction). Any significant interactions will be followed up with Johnson-Neyman values to see at which point(s) along the political ideology spectrum there are significant differences between the responses of those in the past and future conditions. These analyses will be conducted for each environmental outcome variable to determine whether the temporal framing interaction affects pro-environmental attitudes only (H4), or also extends to other forms of environmentalism related to climate change. 

To test H3, if the interaction between political orientation and temporal framing depends on the way that the images are rated (i.e. whether participants rated the perceived causes or effects depicted by the images), we will run a moderated moderation. 

If the rating condition does not affect responses, then data can be collapsed into just past versus future conditions to increase power for mediated moderation analyses. 

If we replicate the temporal framing effect in either rating condition, we will then test the following potential explanations for the effect: nostalgia, past-positive time perspective, temporal distance of climate change, and certainty ratings (H5). Mediated moderation models will be used to see if political ideology is related to the environmental outcome variables through any of these explanatory variables, and whether this effect is moderated by temporal framing condition.

q19.value: For all analyses, we will use the conventional p < .05 to indicate statistical significance.

q21.value: Because any participant who does not finish the study may have stopped responding as they withdrew consent to participate, our ethics protocol dictates that their data is removed.

q22.value: We will conduct some exploratory analyses to explore the role of the dimensions of SDO and RWA in the temporal framing effect. Where these are reported in the final manuscript, they will be clearly labelled as exploratory.

q23.value: We are unable to post the research data on the OSF due to ethics restrictions, however are able to share non-identifiable data with other competent researchers, should they request it.

Two of the potential explanations (Points 1 and 2) for our failure to replicate the temporal framing by political orientation interaction found by Baldwin and Lammers (2016) are testable in this second study we are running. Predictions are as follows:

attributes.title: Power & Language
attributes.description: This study aims to analyze word usage in people who vary with respect to their personal sense of power, dominance, and prestige. Furthermore, we will test whether strangers can infer the level of power, dominance, and prestige of a target based on short written self-descriptions. Brunswik’s lens model analysis is used as theoretical framework.

q1.value: Robert Körner, Jen Overbeck, Astrid Schütz

q2.value: We hypothesize that power, dominance, and prestige will be significantly associated with certain linguistic categories. We also assume that strangers use certain linguistic categories to infer a target’s level of power, dominance, and prestige. As the study is designed in an exploratory fashion and non-experimental we did not derive specific hypotheses regarding the linguistic categories in this protocol.

q3.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value:
Sample 1: Participants of sample 1 (targets) will complete self-rating scales on power, dominance, and prestige. Further, they will briefly describe themselves (up to 5 sentences).

Sample 2: Participants of sample 2 (judges) read the targets’ self-descriptions and complete peer-ratings on the targets power, dominance, and prestige. 
We will use a zero-acquaintance setting.

q8.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
Sample 1: Participants will be recruited through a mailing list. They will live all over Germany. As an incentive they will be offered to participate in a lottery in which three books (Internet und Persönlichkeit [Internet and Personality] by K.-H. Renner, A. Schütz, & F. Machilek) will be offered. The questionnaire will be administered online. Participants must be at least 18 years old. Participants will be excluded if they do not complete the psychological scales or the self-description task. Further, participants with implausible self-descriptions or people who consistently tick one answer will be excluded.

Sample 2: Participants will be recruited at the University of Bamberg. Participants will receive experimental credits for their participation. The questionnaire will be administered online. Participants must be at least 18 years old. If participants indicate familiarity with the target, the peer-rating provided by the participants for the corresponding target will be excluded. Further, participants who consistently tick the same response will be excluded.

q11.value:
Sample 1: An a priori power analysis is used to determine the sample size for the targets. Hirsh and Petersen (2009) report an average correlation between personality and LIWC categories of .23. The power analysis for correlation coefficients (two-tailed, assumed effect size r = .23, α = .05, 1-β = .90) indicates a required sample size of 194 participants. We round up and aim at collecting complete data of 200 participants.

Sample 2: Every target will be judged by 5 persons. Thus, if every judge provides ratings for 10 targets, we will need 100 judges overall. We will do a pilot test whether ratings of 10 persons by one judge are feasible. If fatigue decreases the quality of the ratings, we will recruit more judges and they will rate fewer than 10 targets.

question.value:
Power will be measured with the Personal Sense of Power Scale (Anderson, John, & Keltner, 2012). We will use an adapted German version of this scale.
Dominance and prestige will be measured with the Dominance-Prestige Scales (Cheng, Tracy, & Henrich, 2010).
Both scales are used as self-report and peer-report scales. The latter will be pretested for their suitability as peer-rating version.

We will use the software LIWC2015 (Pennebaker, Boyd, Kayla, & Blackburn, 2015) to analyze frequencies of different word categories in the self-descriptions. We will use correlation analyses for the associations between word frequencies and self-rated as well as peer-rated levels of power, dominance, and prestige. Further, ICCs will be calculate for interrater agreement. Missing values will be replaced with expectation-maximization algorithm.

registration_responses.q1: Robert Körner, Jen Overbeck, Astrid Schütz
registration_responses.q2: We hypothesize that power, dominance, and prestige will be significantly associated with certain linguistic categories. We also assume that strangers use certain linguistic categories to infer a target’s level of power, dominance, and prestige. As the study is designed in an exploratory fashion and non-experimental we did not derive specific hypotheses regarding the linguistic categories in this protocol.

registration_responses.q10.question:
Sample 1: Participants will be recruited through a mailing list. They will live all over Germany. As an incentive they will be offered to participate in a lottery in which three books (Internet und Persönlichkeit [Internet and Personality] by K.-H. Renner, A. Schütz, & F. Machilek) will be offered. The questionnaire will be administered online. Participants must be at least 18 years old. Participants will be excluded if they do not complete the psychological scales or the self-description task. Further, participants with implausible self-descriptions or people who consistently tick one answer will be excluded.

Sample 2: Participants will be recruited at the University of Bamberg. Participants will receive experimental credits for their participation. The questionnaire will be administered online. Participants must be at least 18 years old. If participants indicate familiarity with the target, the peer-rating provided by the participants for the corresponding target will be excluded. Further, participants who consistently tick the same response will be excluded.
registration_responses.q15.question:
Power will be measured with the Personal Sense of Power Scale (Anderson, John, & Keltner, 2012). We will use an adapted German version of this scale.
Dominance and prestige will be measured with the Dominance-Prestige Scales (Cheng, Tracy, & Henrich, 2010).
Both scales are used as self-report and peer-report scales. The latter will be pretested for their suitability as peer-rating version.
registration_responses.q17.question: We will use the software LIWC2015 (Pennebaker, Boyd, Kayla, & Blackburn, 2015) to analyze frequencies of different word categories in the self-descriptions. We will use correlation analyses for the associations between word frequencies and self-rated as well as peer-rated levels of power, dominance, and prestige. Further, ICCs will be calculate for interrater agreement. Missing values will be replaced with expectation-maximization algorithm.

attributes.title: how the color and size of the words influence the memory
attributes.description: My proposed project topic is about how the color and size of the font influence the memory. In other words, there will some words are presented, which are present in variety colors and size. Then I will compare the number of words people recall in each condition.

q2.value: If the color and size of the font affects memory, the mean recalled number of words will be higher when colored and bigger font words are presented.

q3.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value:
We have a between subjects design with 2 factors (color and size) with 2, and 3 levels each. 
so, there will be 6 groups, (colored, small size font), (colored, medium size font), (colored, big size font), (black/white, small size font), (b/w, medium size font), (b/w, big size font). 
each participants will randomly assigned into groups and they will see 10 words for 10 seconds. Then they will recall the words they remembers.

q8.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: To collect data, I will use Qualtrics.

q11.value: my target sample size is minimum 60 participants, which is 10 per group.

question.value:
there will be 6 groups, (colored, small size font), (colored, medium size font), (colored, big size font), (black/white, small size font), (b/w, medium size font), (b/w, big size font). The color will be red, and sizes are 10, 20, 30 each. 
10 words are exposed to participants for 10 seconds, and after participants see words, they asked to write words they remember in the note for 20 seconds.

We will use a two-way between subjects ANOVA to analyze our results. The manipulated, categorical independent variables are "color" and "size" and dependent variable is the number of words they recall.
